citation.article-title: Saccharibacillus sacchari gen. nov., sp. nov., isolated from sugar cane.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Saccharibacillus sacchari sp. nov.
Saccharibacillus sacchari (sac′cha.ri. L. gen. n. sacchari of sugar, referring to the isolation source of the type strain, inner tissues of sugar cane).
Cells are 0.8–1 μm wide and 3–4 μm long.
Motile by means of polar or subpolar flagella.
Spores are formed in a central or subterminal position in cells.
Aerobic or facultatively anaerobic and chemo-organotrophic.
Colonies on TSA are circular with irregular borders, pale pink, not mucoid, opaque and usually 1–2 mm in diameter within 48 h at 28 °C.
Growth occurs at 8–40 °C; optimal growth at 28 °C and pH 7.
Grows in the presence of 2 % NaCl.

Cellulases, xylanases and β-galactosidase are produced actively, but amylases, gelatinase, caseinase, arginine dihydrolase, indole, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase, urease, tryptophan deaminase, phenylalanine deaminase and hydrogen sulfide are not produced.
Acid but not gas is produced from d-glucose.
d-Glucose, mannose, maltose, mannitol and gluconate are used as carbon sources.
Assimilation of l-arabinose, d-xylose, N-acetylglucosamine, caprate, adipate, malate, citrate and phenylacetate is negative.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 57.8 mol%.
The type strain, GR21T (=LMG 24085T =DSM 19268T), was isolated from inner tissues of Saccharum officinarum in Granada (Spain).
